Here in Victoria Tower we hold over four million
historical records from the House of

20.text:

These records really lie at the heart of our

24.text:
They've embodied our liberties, our
rights and responsibilities for the past

28.text:
500 years and include some of the most
important constitutional records in the world.

We preserve all of Parliament's records 
in a wide variety of formats from the

38.text:

Members of the public who want to see
records in the Parliamentary Archives

56.text:
search our online catalogue, they then email us
a list of references of the documents

61.text:
and make an appointment to come in on a
particular day. We then fill out order

64.text:
slips for each document and we go into
the tower

67.text:
every morning to retrieve the material
and bring it down to our search room.

74.text:
Our core staff look at all the order slips
for the day and then figure out which

77.text:
floors they need to go to in the tower so
they can go and plan their journey

81.text:
through the tower and get each batch of
material accordingly.

89.text:
They'll try and fetch out large items
first and then add smaller items along the

93.text:
way and try and avoid going to more
floors than necessary.

96.text:
There are always challenges. When they
designed this building they didn't

99.text:
design it with archives trolleys in mind.
There are 12 floors which hold archive

103.text:
material, about six miles of shelving,
holding more than three million records,

The Victoria Tower was purpose-built
designed as a record repository but it

wasn't designed to have 12 floors and it
didn't have any lifts in it at first

I've never yet had a person who wasn't

237.text:
We really want to make Parliament's
records more accessible and to more people.

240.text:
We want to make it as easy as
possible for you to find the information

244.text:
that you want and then to use it in a
way that is most convenient and useful

249.text:
to you, whether that's here in our public
search room or online from anywhere in the world.

256.text:
The story of Parliament is told through
its records and we act as custodians of

262.text:
those records on behalf of the British
people and our role is to ensure that

266.text:
that story can continue to be told and
understood both now and in the future.
